thread.title: Kotkapura: Tempers still running high

title: Kotkapura: Tempers still running high
text:
Tribune News Service
Moga, October 17
Radical Sikh organisations continued their agitation against the desecration of the ‘bir’ of Guru Granth Sahib in the district for the fifth consecutive day. All national/state highways and major link roads were blocked at 35 locations. The educational institutes and business establishments remained closed at the district headquarters and other towns and villages. Public transport was also suspended. Radical Sikhs armed with swords and sticks then started gathering at a local gurdwara. At Kot-ise-Khan town, 300 Sikh activists armed with swords forced traders to shut down their business establishments. They smashed the flex boards and banners of SADleaders and shouted slogans against them. Similar reports were received from Sangrur, Muktsar, Ferozepur, Abohar, Tarn Taran, Amritsar, Jalandhar, Phagwara and Khanna. SGPC announces Rs 10 lakh each for firing victims Fatehgarh Sahib: The SGPC on Saturday announced a compensation of Rs 10 lakh each to the kin of victims who were killed during police firing at Bargadi village in Kotkapura. SGPC president Avtar Singh Makkar urged the government to register cases under Section 302 against officials who ordered firing on Sikh protesters. He said “akhand paths” would be held in all gurdwaras to pray for peace in the state. — Sanjay Bambroo Another holy book desecrated Mansa: Tension gripped Aklia village of the district after pages torn out of “Panj Granthi” were found in front of Gurdwara Ker Sahib. Residents of Aklia, Joga villages and nearby areas held a protest, after which the police booked unidentified persons.
